node.title: New in Paperback: ‘Mantel Pieces’ and ‘Borges and Me’
node.description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
node.content: ["VANGUARD: How Black Women Broke Barriers, Won the Vote, and Insisted on Equality for All, by Martha S. Jones. (Basic, 368 pp., $18.99.) This deeply researched account highlights the roles of previously overlooked women in the struggle for civil rights in America. \u201cJones has written an elegant and expansive history of Black women who sought to build political power where they could,\u201d noted our critic, Jennifer Szalai.", "FEVERS, FEUDS, AND DIAMONDS: Ebola and the Ravages of History, by Paul Farmer. (Picador, 704 pp., $21.) A medical anthropologist blends history and reportage to examine the factors that led to the 2014 Ebola crisis in West Africa. \u201cFarmer\u2019s book is structured almost like an experimental novel, or a time-twisting prestige television drama,\u201d observed our reviewer, Steven Johnson.", "A CERTAIN HUNGER, by Chelsea G. Summers. (Unnamed Press, 254 pp., $17.) This debut novel relates the story of a homicidal food critic with an insatiable appetite for men. \u201cUniquely fun and campily gory,\u201d as our reviewer, Amy Silverberg, put it, this novel is \u201ca gruesome love letter to rich food and rich men, and to gorging on both with abandon.\u201d", "METROPOLIS: A History of the City, Humankind\u2019s Greatest Invention, by Ben Wilson. (Anchor, 480 pp., $18.) \u201cThe city, as Wilson sees it, is less of a warehouse of architecture and more of an organism that shapes the creatures living inside,\u201d wrote Robert Sullivan, who reviewed the book for us. \u201cMetropolis\u201d is atour spanning thousands of years and covering more than two dozen cities as a way of evaluating how they have shaped human civilization.", "BORGES AND ME: An Encounter, by Jay Parini. (Anchor, 320 pp., $18.) As a young poet living in Scotland, Parini embarked by chance on a road trip with Jorge Luis Borges, an Argentine writer he had never heard of. The bond that the two men created during their journey, commented Michael Greenberg, our reviewer, \u201cis moving, with its unexpected moments of confession and shared fragility.\u201d", "MANTEL PIECES: Royal Bodies and Other Writing From The London Review of Books, by Hilary Mantel. (Fourth Estate, 352 pp., $18.99.) This collection contains about 30 years of Mantel\u2019s essays for The London Review of Books, beginning in 1987. As our reviewer, Fernanda Eberstadt, noted, the book gives a peek into Mantel\u2019s \u201cferociously lucid mind,\u201d and \u201cthe unruly delight of her mocking and self-mocking humor.\u201d"]
